awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Using Ordinal Information to Approximate Cardinal Objectives in Social Choice, Matching, Group Formation, and Assignment Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Many modern algorithms must make decisions using only limited information: they not only need to make the best choices given the input, but also don't know what the "true" input actually is; and yet they are required to make good choices anyway. This problem arises often in settings where the goal is to maximize the total happiness (a.k.a. social welfare or total utility) of the system, such as social choice settings in which voters submit their preferences for different alternatives, matching settings (e.g., matching people with job openings or organ donors with patients), assigning people to groups or projects, economic market settings, and many others. In all of these settings, the people or agents involved may care deeply about which outcome is selected (e.g., which alternative is selected by the voting mechanism, or which patients are assigned a donated kidney), with the mechanism designer's goal being to maximize the overall welfare and satisfaction. Unfortunately, in all these applications, only limited information is usually available: it is relatively easy to obtain *ordinal* information (which choice is preferred to which other choice by each participant), but almost impossible to obtain the underlying numerical information (how *much* each choice is preferred by each participant). This project will use a novel notion of approximation to give new insight into the design and evaluation of many mechanisms for the settings mentioned above. The approximation algorithms resulting from this project will be used to suggest new protocols, which would not only optimize some notion of fairness (as is common in social choice), or maximize the size of a matching (as is common in kidney exchange), but would have provable guarantees on the quality of the outcomes. One reason why such guarantees have not been considered in the past is that without the knowledge of exact numerical utilities or exact compatibilities between matches, protocols can only rely on ordinal, or otherwise limited, information. However, as preliminary work shows, one can often design algorithms which behave well no matter what the *true* information is, as long as the underlying (unknown) numerical values have some reasonable structure, or are at least correlated in some way, which is certainly the case for most applications. Because of this, this project will provide a different perspective, and will result in algorithms which produce provably good outcomes while using only limited ordinal information.  Due to the applications touched by this project, the work done should be of interest to researchers in many fields, including Social Choice, Artificial Intelligence, Game Theory, Social Networks, and Economics. This research will be strongly complemented by the PI's education plan, which includes teaching several courses with research components, presenting this work at numerous scientific seminars, and recruiting several graduate and undergraduate students to work on this project.

The primary goal of this project is to design and analyze algorithms which only know ordinal information, and yet create solutions which are provably close to the "true" optimal solution: the one which would be chosen if the full numerical information were known. The project will specifically focus on the settings of social choice, matching, group formation, and economic markets. Very little is known about approximation algorithms in the presence of ordinal information, and designing such algorithms for the settings above will likely require new and interesting techniques. When the numerical values are completely uncorrelated, it is of course impossible to form good approximations from only ordinal information, so this work will involve looking at different kinds of correlations (e.g., lying in a metric space, symmetric values, values from a common distribution, etc), and determining how much power this structure gives to the ordinal information, as compared to the true numerical information. The PI will also consider optimization problems with other interesting constraints which deserve further study, focusing especially on computing good solutions in the presence of self-interested agents, in the contexts of social choice, matching, and envy-free pricing. This work should lead to basic understanding of the fundamental power of ordinal information, by determining under which settings and conditions ordinal information is enough to approximate the numerical truth, and when such an approximation is impossible.

por.por_cntn:
Modern algorithms must produce good outcomes despite being given only a very small amount of information, and never knowing what is "truly going on". Consider, for example, the setting of social choice (i.e., voting), in which voters attempt to come up with a consensus choice from among many outcomes. This can refer to political elections, voting in committees, or simply a group of friends deciding where to go for dinner. While the voters often have strong opinions about the quality of outcomes ("Outcome A is great! Outcome B is terrible! Outcome C is terrible too, but nowhere near as bad as B!"), most voting mechanisms only make use of the voters' *ordinal* preferences (in other words: only the ordering "A is better than C is better than B"), and do not take into account the strength of these preferences. The goals of this project were to: (1) Understand how well such ordinal mechanisms perform compared to mechanisms which know the exact strengths of voter preferences, and (2) To design better mechanisms which only use limited ordinal information, but still perform almost as well as omniscient mechanisms. This project did not only concern social choice problems: the same issues arise in matching settings (e.g., matching workers with jobs), when breaking up people into collaborative groups, and in many other settings where people or companies may have strong preferences about the outcome, but it is only feasible to obtain their ordinal preferences. The focus of this project was on provable guarantees and algorithm design, and especially on quantifying the "distortion" of various algorithms, which measures how well algorithms with only ordinal information perform compared to algorithms which know the true preference strengths.

For the settings described above, this project quantified the distortion of many well-known mechanisms, formulated novel mechanisms with good performance (small distortion), and formulated bounds on how well *any* algorithm which is only aware of ordinal information can perform in various settings. The project also quantified the amounts of information about user preferences needed for various algorithms to perform well in social choice and matching settings, and how this performance improves as the amount of information grows. The high-level insights from this project are as follows. (1) As long as the voter/user preferences have a nice structure (for example if they are embeddable into a metric space) then there is no reason to spend lots of time and money figuring out the strengths of these preferences: instead it is possible to form ordinal mechanisms which perform almost as well. (2) For many settings, if there is an efficient algorithm which requires full knowledge of user preference strengths, there are general techniques which can be used to convert this algorithm into an ordinal algorithm, with only a small degradation in its performance. (3) In social choice and matching settings, even a few bits of extra information can greatly improve this distortion of a mechanism, as long as it is the correct few bits. Thus when forming mechanisms for social welfare, it is crucial to ask users the correct questions about their preferences, and not just to collect generic preference information.
